abstract.p: Governmental pressures on the drug industry are mounting. To a very large extent the problems of this industry derive indirectly from the failure of economists to resolve questions of cost of capital in a dynamic economy. As a result of this failure drug-industry profits are being judged excessive when in fact no sound theoretical basis exists for such a judgment. In this paper the weaknesses of prevailing economic theory are described, and efforts are made to show the direction in which theory must move if the drug industry is to be judged fairly. It is difficult to prove through objective measures that competition is not effective in this industry. Deliberate governmental efforts to reduce industry returns may therefore have a very unfavorable impact on private competitive research effort.
